x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.problem_statement:
During natural disasters or humanitarian crises, nonprofit organizations and local authorities often face fragmented communication and poor coordination. Requests for aid such as food, medicine, or rescue support arrive through multiple disconnected channels (email, WhatsApp, phone calls), leading to duplicate efforts, delayed responses, and wasted resources. Victims may wait hours or days before help reaches them, not because aid is unavailable, but because it isn’t efficiently organized or prioritized.
There is an urgent need for a centralized, intelligent workflow system that can coordinate aid requests, resources, and volunteers in real time.

How do you envision the ideal solution to this  problem?

 

Which ServiceNow products or capabilities would be used?

AidCare would be a ServiceNow-based platform that automates the entire disaster response workflow.

Key features:

  • AI-powered intake system: Collects requests from multiple channels (web form, email, chatbot).
  • AI classification & prioritization: Uses Predictive Intelligence to categorize cases (medical aid, shelter, logistics) and urgency.
  • Automated task assignment: Flow Designer routes cases to the right NGO or volunteer group based on location and availability.
  • Real-time dashboard: Displays requests, resources, and delivery status for all stakeholders.
  • Analytics & reporting: Tracks performance metrics to support continuous improvement and accountability.


    ServiceNow App Engine     – to build the core workflow application.

         Flow Designer – for automating assignments, notifications, and follow-ups.

         Predictive Intelligence / AI Search – to classify and prioritize incoming requests.

         Virtual Agent – to handle 24/7 chat based support or intake.

         Field Service Management – for tracking volunteers, assets, and deliveries.

        Dashboards and Reporting – for real-time visibility and analytics.

 

Are there any technical dependencies for the proposed solution?

Integration with external APIs such as Google Maps (for location tracking and routing).

Messaging APIs (Twilio, WhatsApp) for communication automation.

Optional integration with open disaster databases or local NGO data sources for richer insights.

 

What challenges would you foresee in implementing this idea?

Data standardization: Different NGOs use varied formats for reporting and requests.

Access to real-time data: May depend on cooperation and openness from external partners.

User adoption: Nonprofit staff and volunteers may require training to use a new platform effectively.

Connectivity limitations: Disaster zones may have unstable internet access.

AI accuracy: Requires sufficient data to train classification models for local contexts.
